arguments.facts: On March 3, 2024, the plaintiff arrived at the defendant’s premises at approximately 9:15 a.m. to perform a scheduled delivery. The defendant’s manager, Mr. [REDACTED], improperly demanded a retroactive amendment to the delivery receipt, insisting the plaintiff sign a new receipt changing the date to March 5. When the plaintiff refused, the defendant’s security guard barred the plaintiff’s exit, creating a coercive environment. The plaintiff’s supervisor intervened at 9:45 a.m., resolving the matter after a 30‑minute unlawful detention.
arguments.issues: Whether the defendant’s actions constitute a breach of contract and wrongful coercion, justifying a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6).
authorities: Doe v. Acme Corp., 987 F.2d 321 (Cal. Ct. App. 2018)

messages.content:
Opening Narrative (Draft):

The plaintiff, a reputable supplier, fulfilled its contractual obligations by arriving at the defendant’s facility on March 3, 2024, at approximately 9:15 a.m., ready to deliver the goods as scheduled. Upon arrival, the defendant’s manager, Mr. [REDACTED], unilaterally demanded that the plaintiff sign a revised receipt that retroactively altered the delivery date to March 5, a demand unsupported by any prior agreement. When the plaintiff reasonably refused, the defendant’s security personnel barred the plaintiff’s exit, effectively detaining the plaintiff for thirty minutes and creating a coercive atmosphere that threatened the plaintiff’s professional reputation and business operations. The plaintiff’s supervisor arrived at 9:45 a.m. and resolved the impasse, underscoring the unreasonable nature of the defendant’s conduct.

This conduct not only breaches the express terms of the delivery contract but also amounts to wrongful coercion, as recognized in Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020), and Doe v. Acme Corp., 987 F.2d 321 (Cal. Ct. App. 2018). Accordingly, the plaintiff respectfully moves to dismiss the defendant’s counter‑claims under Rule 12(b)(6), as they fail to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.
